awd_titl_txt: Statistical Learning for High-Dimensional Relational Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Technological advances in data acquisition, digital observation, and storage have produced an explosion in high-dimensional datasets that are often too large and noisy for traditional data analysis tools. In many cases these high-dimensional datasets are transformed into relational data that summarize relations between pairs of entities in the original dataset. There are two major classes of statistical methods for analyzing such relational data: techniques from classical multivariate analysis and probabilistic graphical models. These two classes are often viewed as disparate yet complementary approaches to relational data analysis. However, both can fail from being overwhelmed by noise and high-dimensionality. This research project proposes a new framework that unifies these two classes of methods under the umbrella of regularized statistical learning, and it will address three important issues: (1) it will reveal important conceptual links between these disparate methods, thus providing a common ground for developing new and hybrid methods; (2) it will advance theoretical understanding of these methods especially in the case of high-dimensional and noisy data; (3) it will advance computational techniques that enable these methods to be applied to big data that is high-dimensional and large-scale.

Statistical theory has shown that traditional multivariate methods can fail on high-dimensional data and that some form of regularization is necessary for estimation. Despite the recent surge in development of regularized methods, there still exists a gap between the methodological developments and theoretical understanding. This research project fills this gap by combining methodological development with theoretical insight to produce a unified family of regularized methods for relational data that are both computationally efficient and theoretically sound. The theoretical insights will reveal the statistical properties of the methods under very weak assumptions, and they will enable computational strategies that exploit hidden structure in the optimization problems underlying the methods.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Many large data sets are often transformed into relational data that summarizes the relationships between pairs of entities in the original dataset. This type of "relational" data is often analyzed my disparate statistical methods spanning two different points of view: classical multivariate analysis and more contemporary probabilistic graphical modeling. We set out this project to identify conceptual links between these different classes of methods.


The major scientific achievement of this project is the discovery of a new theoretical framework, "computational sufficiency" that enables us to make formal conceptual links between seemingly disparate data analysis procedures. This discovery came about from our study of statistical learning methods for high-dimensional relational data at the start of the project, and it shows that these methods can be linked together through a common data reduction. This enables both more efficient computation of these methods and also gives a different conceptual understanding of the methods in a model-free setting requiring fewer assumptions. These discoveries are described in detail in the manuscripts produced by the project that we have made publicly available.


In addition to scientific discoveries, this project has also supported the training of a large group of students. These students contributed to the research in the project and this project also helped prepared the students with skills for successful careers in industry. These students are now working in industry among an emerging workforce of data scientists.


Last Modified: 01/31/2022
Modified by: Vincent Q Vu
